titleStmt.title: Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.4

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.4

supportDesc.support: Composite volume. All Parts are of parchment, with paper endleaves.

foliation.note: Foliated in dark brown ink in the upper outer corner of each recto. The paper endleaves were assigned folio designations in April 2023 in order to prepare the record for online presentation as part of the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries Project; these designations have been enclosed in [square brackets].

supportDesc.collation:
A composite volume with quires of mostly 12 and 8 leaves arranged in the following way:
Quires 1-812 (ff. 1-96)
Quire 98 (ff. 97-104) |
Quires 10-118 (ff. 105-120)
Quire 1210 (ff. 121-130)
Quire 138 (ff. 131-138)
Quire 1412-2 (4th and 5th leaf cancelled; ff. 139-148) |
Quire 154 (ff. 149-152) |
Quire 164 (ff. 153-156)
Quire 1712 (ff. 157-168)
Quire 18two (ff. 169-170)
Quire 1912-1 (1st leaf cancelled; ff. 171-181)
1-812 98 | 10-118 1210 138 1412-2 (4th and 5th leaf cancelled) | 154 | 164 1712 18 two (two leaves remain) 19 12-1 (1st leaf cancelled)
No leaf signatures common to the entire volume.
Quires are numbered in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire. No catchwords common to the entire volume.

binding.p: Fully bound in calf over paste- or mill- board with matching blind-impressed decoration to left and right covers. The cover material is decorated with a feather-and-bead roll set at the perimeter of each board. The head, fore, and tail edges of the cover material, and also the turn ins are decorated with a hatched diagonal roll. Head and tail bands are visible and wrapped in alternating segments of pink and blue yarn. Four raised bands on the spine, each decorated with the hatched diagonal roll used elsewhere on the binding. Spine compartments not used for titles are decorated with a scale motif, some 'scales' enclosing a futher lobed or 'cloud' motif conforming to the shape of the scale. Title tooled in gold: 'M.S.S'.

Pastedowns of grey-brown paper at each end of the volume. The right pastedown is blank. The left pastedown contains:
The manuscript's shelfmark, 'D.4' in ink
A St John's College bookplate
A bookplate recording the donation of the volume by William Crashaw
Folded bifolia of stiff grey-brown paper at each end of the volume for the endleaves (ff. [i]-[ii] and [iii]-[iv].

provenance.p: Purchased at an unknown time before 1624 by William Crashaw Crashaw, William, 1572-1626 , a lawyer, book collector, and former Johnian. In his lifetime Crashaw's collection numbered around 200 manuscripts and 1000 printed books.

The manuscripts and printed books owned by William Crashaw were purchased by
Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton Southampton, Henry Wriothesley, Earl of, 1573-1624 , at an unknown time before Wriothesley's death in 1624. Wriothesley had been a student-contemporary of Crashaw at St John's College and he purchased Crashaw's collection with the intention to present the volumes as a gift to the Library of St John's College. The library was still partly under construction at the time of the purchase resulting in the Wriothesley family storing Crashaw's collection and delivering it piecemeal to the College over a number of years.

After Henry Wriothesley's death in 1624, care of Crashaw's books and manuscripts passed to Wriothesley's son, Thomas Wriothesley, 4th Earl of Southampton Southampton, Thomas Wriothesley, Earl of, 1607-1667 . Although Crashaw's printed books seem to have passed swiftly to the College, Thomas Wriothesley seems to have taken a particular interest in the manuscripts, adding his name (typically in the form Tho: C. S. for 'Thomas comes southamptoniensis') to most of them, and apparently exhibiting such reluctance to deliver the manuscripts that the College wrote to his mother, Elizabeth Vernon Southampton, Elizabeth Vernon Wriothesley, Countess of, 1573-1655? to ask her to encourage her son to hand over the manuscript volumes.

history.acquisition: Given to St Johnâs College in 1635 by Thomas Wriothesley, 4th Earl of Southampton Southampton, Thomas Wriothesley, Earl of, 1607-1667 on behalf of William Crashaw Crashaw, William, 1572-1626 and Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton Southampton, Henry Wriothesley, Earl of, 1573-1624 . A bookplate recording the Crashaw-Wriothesley donation is present on the left pastedown.

recordHist.source: This catalogue record draws on: M. H. Green, 'Appendix - Medieval Gynecological Texts: A Handlist', in M. H. Green (ed.), Womenâs Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), Appendix pp. 1-36 M. H. Green, 'The De Genecia Attributed to Constantine the African', in M. H. Green (ed.), Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), pp. III:299-324 M. R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of St John's College (Cambridge, 1913)

availability.p: Visitors to St John's College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: St John's College: Old Library and Special Collections.

msItem.title: Antidotarium (Pomum ambre)
msItem.incipit: 1r Pomum ambre duplicatum ad reuma suspendendum
msItem.note: Incipit incorrectly transcribed in eTK. Note that the eTK entry suggests that this text ends on f. 81v.

msItem.incipit: 22v Undecimo ex operatione docti auctoris est indicare
msItem.note: Attributed to Alexander of Hales Alexander, of Hales (approximately 1185-1245) in the manuscript.

msItem.explicit: 32r lac autem salsum male oloris infantis nutrimento non est conueniens

msItem.title: De febribus
msItem.incipit: 39r Egritudinum quedam sunt acute quedam diuturne teste Galieno
msItem.explicit: 43v operandam est in causone secundum magister asteracis
msItem.note: This text is sometimes attributed to Ricardus Anglicus Ricardus Anglicus (Richard of England) (d. ?1252)
This text is also in Paris, BibliothÃ¨que nationale de France, MS Latin 6976, ff. 128v-129v (defective at end).

msItem.title: Gloss on 'Antidotarium'
msItem.incipit: 43v Febris tria sunt ex .iii. quod humanum corpus constituunt

msItem.incipit: 82r Sit porcina recens caro prestita flegbotomato

listBibl.bibl: Walther, Initia carminum, no. 18323

msItem.title: Treatise on the Four Humours
msItem.rubric: 83r Incipit liber magistri Petri de Salerno transpositus a latino in romanum ad instanciam Margarum fregille regine yspanie de omnibus opinionibus uniuersorum magistrorum tunc salerine commorancium
msItem.incipit: 83r Humaine cors est ke ist de quatre humors . De sanc . De ruge colre . Et de neir colre . Et de fleume
msItem.note: This text is printed in Hefferman, 'Wyse Boke', pp. 319-320.

Carol Hefferman identified a related text in Middle English preserved in Philadelphia, College of Physicians of Philadelphia, MS 10a. 215, Part III, ff. 23r-40v (formerly Philadelphia, College of Physicians of Philadelphia, MS Med. Misc. I, No. 3, ff. 1râ18v), with the rubric: 'Here beynnyth the wyse boke of maystyr Peers of Salerne as he transposyd it owte of lateyn in to englysche at ye requeste and desyre of Margerye ffygyll the qwene of Spayne. And as it was affermyd by ye opynyons of alle the maystres that time in Sallerne dwellynge'. Unfortunately, scholars have not been able to securely attach the names 'Margarum fregille' or 'Margerye ffygyll' to a Spanish monarch, or any other identifiable person.

Salvatore de Renzi, Storia Documentata Della Scuola Medica Salernitana, 2nd edn (Naples, 1857), esp. p. 166

msItem.title: Physique rimee (Medieval French)
msItem.incipit: 83r Home ki ueut asescriz entender . Bele resun ipoet aprender
msItem.explicit: 99r Par tut gardez ki soit ouel . Od ewe teue le deit temprer
msItem.note:
This text is discussed extensively in Hunt, Popular Medicine. Hunt also prints several portions of this text in a comparative edition with:
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.20, ff. 1r-21r
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.27, Part 3, ff. 1r-3r
London, British Library, Sloane MS 146
London, British Library, Sloane MS 3550
Hefferman, 'Wyse Boke' (1993) prints some of the recipes for 'cancre' on ff. 95v-96r.

listBibl.bibl: Monica Green, 'The Possibilities of Literacy and the Limits of Reading: Women and the Gendering of Medical Literacy' in M. Green (ed.) Womenâs Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Ashgate, 2000), p. 1-76, esp. pp. 64, 71
Tony Hunt, Popular Medicine in Thirteenth-Century England: Introduction and Texts (Cambridge, 1990), esp. p. 106, 142-216, 295-296
Carol F. Heffernan, âThe Wyse Boke of Maystyr Peers of Salerne: Edition and Study of a Fourteenth-Century Treatise of Popular Medicineâ, Manuscripta 37, (1993) pp. 290â321, esp. 319-321.

msItem.title: Medical recipes deriving from the 'Lettre d'Hippocrate'
msItem.rubric: 99r Pur la dolor de la teste
msItem.incipit: 99r Phol qint en ensis destempe
msItem.explicit: 100v si le beiuez Â·iiiÂ· jors al matin e al seir
msItem.note:
This text is discussed in Hunt, Popular Medicine. Hunt discusses this text and several other versions of the 'Lettre d'Hippocrate' in Hunt, Popular Medicine, and draws attention to several manuscripts that preserve portions of this text and also versions of the Physique rimee:
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.20, ff. 1r-21r
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.27, Part 3, ff. 1r-3r
London, British Library, Sloane MS 146
London, British Library, Sloane MS 3550

listBibl.bibl: Tony Hunt, Popular Medicine in Thirteenth-Century England: Introduction and Texts (Cambridge, 1990), pp. 100-141, 149, 295-296

msItem.title: Medical recipes and notes
msItem.note: In several hands. The final recipe begins on f. 104v and crosses into the lower margin of f. 105r, a separate Part of the manuscript; this shows that these two Parts have been bound together since the late 13th or early 14th century.

signatures.p: Medieval alphanumeric leaf signatures (symbols and letters with Roman numerals), written in blue ink, in the lower margins of the rectos in the first halves of some quires as follows:
No medieval quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in ink in the lower margin of the last verso of each quire.

supportDesc.condition: Trimmed for rebinding with minor loss of marginal annotations. Folios 1-2 wormed. Some leaves of slightly irregular size due to natural variation in the parchment. Some leaves rubbed and stained, but most leaves legible.

p.seg: Ruled in ink and leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in double-column format, typically 40-41 lines to the column and written below top line.

handNote.p: Main texts written in gothic cursive antiquior.

decoNote.p: Plain initials in blue and occasionally in red at the major and minor divisions of the texts.
Some texts have rubrics and chapter headings in red ink.
Paraph marks in red and blue.
Guide letters visible in the margins adjacent to decorative initials, see e.g., f. 85v.

note.p: Partial list of the contents of the volume in a late 15th or early 16th century hand in the outer margin of f. 1r: 'Autores huius libri Alexander de Hales Petrus de Salerno Platearius Muscio Theodorus Priscianus'.
Several anotators have added keywords and glosses to the margins of all of the texts in this Part.

binding.p: This Part of the manuscript was probably once situated as the first part of a manuscript with wood boards. Folios 1-2 have worm damage characteristic of leaves adjacent to wormed wooden binding boards.

origin.origDate: Written in the thirteenth or fourteenth century, probably close to c. 1300.

provenance.p: This Part of the manuscript (ff. 1-104) and the next Part of the manuscript (ff. 105-148) have been bound together since the 14th century as an annotator writing a late 13th or early 14th century added a medical recipe to f. 104v and continued the text into the lower margin of f. 105r.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College MS D.4, ff. 105-148

msItem.title: De simplicibus medicinae ('Circa instans')
msItem.author: Mattheus Platearius (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: 105r Circa instans negotium

msItem.title: Medical aphorism attributed to the Medical School in Salerno
msItem.incipit: 147r Pro uanis uerbis montanis utimur herbis
msItem.explicit: 147r Pro certis rebus pigmentis et speciebus
msItem.note: Written in bright yellow ink and enclosed in a decorative yellow frame.

msItem.title: Lapidiary text
msItem.incipit: 147v-148r Lapis magnes gignitur atque inuenitur circa litus occeani apud rogoditas
msItem.note: Folio 148v blank.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
Quires 10-13 numbered in ink in Roman numerals I-IV.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in ink in the lower margin of the last verso of each quire, some lost to trimming.

supportDesc.condition: Trimmed for binding with minor loss of text from some marginal annotations see e.g., f. 121v.

p.seg: Ruled in brown crayon frame and lines. Ruled in double-column format, typically 43 lines to the column, written above top line.

handNote.p: Written in a protogothic minuscule in a style typical of Italian scribal work in the 12th century. Additional texts on ff. 147r-148r are by a different scribe writing a more elongated form of the script.

decoNote.p: Major initials are in two colours, typically red letterforms with yellow in the counterspaces.
Minor initials in red, some with occasional 'Arabesque' flourishing.
Chapter headings in red, the first letter sometimes touched with yellow.
Black paraph marks touched with red.

note.p: Extensive marginal annotations throughout this Part in several medieval hands.

provenance.p: This Part of the manuscript (ff. 105-148) and the previous Part of the manuscript (ff. 1-104) have been bound together since the 14th century, since an annotator writing a late 13th or early 14th century added a medical recipe to f. 104v and continued the text into the lower margin of f. 105r.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.4, ff. 149-152

msItem.title: Table of contents for the texts on ff. 153-181v
msItem.incipit: 149r Incipiunt capitula tractatus libri primi muscionis de mulierum membris et earum causis obstetricalibus de greco in latinum translatus
msItem.explicit: 152v Explicit liber quintus genecie theodori preciani de mulierum cura.
msItem.note: This list of contents on two additional nested bifolia, in an English hand of the 14th or 15th century.

support.material: Parchment (HFFH). Leaves are slightly shorter (c. 20-30mm) than all of the other leaves used for this volume.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in double-column format for a chapter list, typically 41 lines to the column and written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a legible northern textualis currens in England in the 14th century.

decoNote.p: No significant decorative features in this Part.

origin.p: Monica Green discusses the origin of Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.4 in several works, but in particular see M. H. Green, 'The De Genecia Attributed to Constantine the African', in M. H. Green (ed.), Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), p. III:302, esp. n. 11, where she quotes Consuelo Dutschke's assessment that this list of the contents of ff. 153-181 was added to the volume in England in the 14th century.

provenance.p: Monica Green discusses the origin of Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.4 in several works, but in particular see M. H. Green, 'The De Genecia Attributed to Constantine the African', in M. H. Green (ed.), Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), p. III:302, esp. n. 11, where she quotes Consuelo Dutschke's assessment of the manuscript as follows: 'By the fourteenth century it had moved to England, as evidenced by the chapter list added at the beginning of the manuscript [i.e., fols. 149-152]. An English hand continued to annotate it during the fifteenth century.'

msItem.title: Prologue to the Gynaecia

msItem.title: Gynaecia (abbreviated version)
msItem.author: (pseudo-)Cleopatra
msItem.incipit: 171r Desideranti tibi filia karissima et habere uolenti commentarium curationis mulierum facere laboraui
msItem.note: There are two surviving medieval versions of a text known as Gynaecia attributed to Queen Cleopatra of Egypt, a longer one, and an abbreviated version based on the longer one. The version here on ff. 171r-173r is the abbreviated version. See Green, 'Appendix', Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West', Appendix pp. 8-10 for further information.

msItem.title: Ad Octauium filium
msItem.author: (pseudo-) Theodorus Priscianus
msItem.incipit: 179r Sanguinem menstrualem prouocat nitrum et farina munda ex oleo myrraceo
msItem.explicit: 180v cum uino optimo da sed uidere ne emorroidas patiatur
msItem.note: Prologue not present. Note that the text is not especially close to the edition printed by Rose. The version of the text in Cambridge, St John's College MS D.4 is close to another version noted by M. Green, Madrid, Biblioteca Nacional, MS 4234, ff. 25r-28r.

msItem.incipit: 180v De passionibus mulierem utile preuidi uobis scribere sruenientibus plurimis et diuersis passionibus sepius de matre
msItem.explicit: 180v Debet uero in potu semel et tertium

listBibl.bibl: M. H. Green, 'Appendix - Medieval Gynecological Texts: A Handlist', in M. H. Green (ed.), Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), Appendix pp. 1-36, esp. p. 25
M. H. Green, 'The De Genecia Attributed to Constantine the African', in M. H. Green (ed.), Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), p. III:299-324, esp. n. 10, 45
M. H. Green, 'The De Genecia Attributed to Constantine the African', in M. H. Green (ed.), Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), p. III:299-324, esp. n. 45

msItem.title: De genetalibus membris (excerpts from ch. 1)
msItem.author: Constantinus Africanus (attrib.)
msItem.rubric: 181r De genetalis membris et primum de matrice
msItem.incipit: 181r Matrix in forma est sicut uescia cuius maxima est profunditas
msItem.explicit: 181v sed tamen ego nullum uidi qui fateretur se uidisse
msItem.note: As described by M. H. Green, the text known as De genetailbus membris is an excerpt from Constantinus Africanus' Pantegni, Theorica, Bk. III, chs. 33-36 that circulated indepently of the larger work.

listBibl.bibl: M. H. Green, 'Appendix - Medieval Gynecological Texts: A Handlist', in M. H. Green (ed.), Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), Appendix pp. 1-36, esp. p. 10
M. H. Green, 'The De Genecia Attributed to Constantine the African', in M. H. Green (ed.), Women's Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), p. III:299-324, esp. n. 45

support.material: Parchment (HFFH). Most leaves are slightly irregular in size. Folio 170 is half the width of the other leaves in this Part, but the text conforms to the shape of the leaf.

signatures.p: No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part.

catchwords.seg: No catchwords particular to this Part.

supportDesc.condition: Leaves have been trimmed for rebinding with loss of instruction-text along the edges of some leaves. Some leaves have small tears and holes.

p.seg: Ruled mostly in drypoint and occasionally in ink, frame and lines. Ruled mostly in single-column format, typically 45 lines to the page and written above top line. Pricking visible in outer margin of several leaves in this Part, e.g., f. 172. Lists of capitula are presented in double-column format, but are not presented with an extra vertical column rule, see e.g., f. 173r.

handNote.p: Written in protogothic minuscule but retaining several features of Caroline minuscule by at least two scribes working in Italy in the first half of the 12th century.
Headings in this Part are written in Rustic Captials.

decoNote.p: Marginal diagram of a womb in the outer margin of f. 153r; the diagram accompanies Muscio's Gynaecia, which has a cycle of images common to several copies of the text, but the diagram in St John's College MS D.4 represents an extreme simplification of the typical diagram. No other diagrams accompany the text.
Major initials, typically in red and green with 'Arabesque' flourishing at major divisions of the texts.
Minor initials typically in red (sometimes green, dark brown, ochre, yellow), with occasional 'Arabesque' flourishing.
Chapter titles typically in two styles: 1) Caroline minuscule in red or green ink 2) rustic capitals in brown ink on a green wash.

note.p: Many of the texts in this Part have been supplied with explicits by a 15th century ?English scribe who also added marginal annotations to some of the texts.
Glosses and additional recipes added in the margins in several medieval hands.

origin.origDate: Probably written in the first half of the 12th century.

note.p: Monica Green discusses the origin of Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.4 in several works, but in particular see M. H. Green, âThe De Genecia Attributed to Constantine the Africanâ, in M. H. Green (ed.), Womenâs Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), p. III:302, esp. n. 11, where she shares Consuelo Dutschke's assessment of the manuscript as follows: ' ... copied in Italy during the first half of the twelfth century...'.

provenance.p: Monica Green discusses the origin of Cambridge, St John's College, MS D.4 in several works, but in particular see M. H. Green, âThe De Genecia Attributed to Constantine the Africanâ, in M. H. Green (ed.), Womenâs Healthcare in the Medieval West Texts and Contexts (Aldershot, 2000), p. III:302, esp. n. 11, where she quotes Consuelo Dutschke's assessment of the manuscript as follows: 'By the fourrteenth century it had moved to England, as evidenced by the chapter list added at the beginning of the manuscript [i.e., fols. 149-152]. An English hand continued to annotate it during the fifteenth century.'

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
